bio:treatment.discussion: Species of Polytrichastrum have a peristome of the leiodont type (S. O. Lindberg 1868). The capsule is terete or obtusely (in fresh capsules) 4–6-angled, the apophysis tapering or short-cylindric but not sharply separated from the rest of the capsule by a deep basal constriction. The epiphragm is loosely attached and early deciduous. Capsules are pale greenish or yellowish brown rather than dark brown or purplish, and not glaucous when fresh as in Polytrichum. The exothecial cells are not bulging mammillose or pitted, but may have a diffuse thin spot on the outer wall. Spores are papillose rather than minutely echinulate as in Polytrichum. Polytrichastrum alpinum is distinct genetically from other members of the genus (G. S. Derda et al. 1999). Other Polytrichastrum species show evidence of allopolyploid origin, possibly involving interspecific or even intergeneric hybridization between species of Polytrichastrum and Polytrichum.

references.reference: Smith, Gary L. 1992. Notes on North American Polytrichaceae: Polytrichastrum G. Sm. Bryologist 95: 270–273.

key_statement.description: Lamellae coarsely papillose; capsules terete, long-cylindric to ovate-cylindric to suborbicular.
Lamellae margins entire in profile; exothecial cells without thin spot
Lamellae margins crenate in profile, the marginal cells crowned by a papillose knob;
Lamellae not papillose (rarely faintly striate-papillose); capsules 4–6-angled.
Marginal cells of lamellae in section narrow, pyriform, thickened in the narrowed apex
Marginal cells of lamellae in section wider than those beneath, flat-topped or shallowly retuse
Marginal lamina entire or obscurely denticulate, inflexed; leaf apex cucullate, rarely bluntly mucronate
Marginal lamina toothed, plane or erect, not inflexed; leaf apex ending in a short awn.
Marginal cells of lamellae in section wider than those beneath, transversely elliptic, the free wall conspicuously thickened, often brownish
Marginal cells of lamellae ovate to elliptic, usually slightly taller than wide, not or evenly thickened.
Marginal lamina 5–9(–20) cells wide, somewhat incurved when dry; median sheath cells rectangular (3–5:1)
Marginal lamina 2–5 cells wide, ± erect; median sheath cells elongate
